trailingComments.value:
*
 * @desc
 * Using the parameters of the last level, this function computes PTS' of the new fragments so that they form a
 * contiguous stream with the last fragments.
 * The PTS of a fragment lets Hls.js know where it fits into a stream - by knowing every PTS, we know which fragment to
 * download at any given time. PTS is normally computed when the fragment is demuxed, so taking this step saves us time
 * and an extra download.
 * @lineNumber
 * 94
 * @param
 * {undefined} lastFrag
 * @param
 * {undefined} lastLevel
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details

*
 * @desc
 * Using the parameters of the last level, this function computes PTS' of the new fragments so that they form a
 * contiguous stream with the last fragments.
 * The PTS of a fragment lets Hls.js know where it fits into a stream - by knowing every PTS, we know which fragment to
 * download at any given time. PTS is normally computed when the fragment is demuxed, so taking this step saves us time
 * and an extra download.
 * @lineNumber
 * 94
 * @param
 * {undefined} lastFrag
 * @param
 * {undefined} lastLevel
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details

leadingComments.value:
*
 * @desc
 *
 * @lineNumber
 * 71
 * @param
 * {number} sliding
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
If the PTS wasn't figured out via discontinuity sequence that means there was no CC increase within the level.
Aligning via Program Date Time should therefore be reliable, since PDT should be the same within the same
discontinuity sequence.
Try to align on sn so that we pick a better start fragment.
Do not perform this on playlists with delta updates as this is only to align levels on switch
and adjustSliding only adjusts fragments after skippedSegments.

 * @lineNumber

trailingComments.value: if last level sliding is 1000 and its first frag PROGRAM-DATE-TIME is 2017-08-20 1:10:00 AM
and if new details first frag PROGRAM DATE-TIME is 2017-08-20 1:10:08 AM
then we can deduce that playlist B sliding is 1000+8 = 1008s

leadingComments.value: This check protects the unsafe "!" usage below for null program date time access.

trailingComments.value: hasProgramDateTime check above makes this safe.

leadingComments.value: if last level sliding is 1000 and its first frag PROGRAM-DATE-TIME is 2017-08-20 1:10:00 AM
and if new details first frag PROGRAM DATE-TIME is 2017-08-20 1:10:08 AM
then we can deduce that playlist B sliding is 1000+8 = 1008s

trailingComments.value: date diff is in ms. frag.start is in seconds

leadingComments.value: hasProgramDateTime check above makes this safe.
date diff is in ms. frag.start is in seconds

*
 * @desc
 * Computes the PTS of a new level's fragments using the difference in Program Date Time from the last level.
 * @lineNumber
 * 152
 * @param

 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} lastDetails

trailingComments.value:
*
 * @desc
 * Ensures appropriate time-alignment between renditions based on PDT. Unlike `alignPDT`, which adjusts
 * the timeline based on the delta between PDTs of the 0th fragment of two playlists/`LevelDetails`,
 * this function assumes the timelines represented in `refDetails` are accurate, including the PDTs,
 * and uses the "wallclock"/PDT timeline as a cross-reference to `details`, adjusting the presentation
 * times/timelines of `details` accordingly.
 * Given the asynchronous nature of fetches and initial loads of live `main` and audio/subtitle tracks,
 * the primary purpose of this function is to ensure the "local timelines" of audio/subtitle tracks
 * are aligned to the main/video timeline, using PDT as the cross-reference/"anchor" that should
 * be consistent across playlists, per the HLS spec.
 * @lineNumber
 * 191
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} refDetails

*
 * @desc
 * Ensures appropriate time-alignment between renditions based on PDT. Unlike `alignPDT`, which adjusts
 * the timeline based on the delta between PDTs of the 0th fragment of two playlists/`LevelDetails`,
 * this function assumes the timelines represented in `refDetails` are accurate, including the PDTs,
 * and uses the "wallclock"/PDT timeline as a cross-reference to `details`, adjusting the presentation
 * times/timelines of `details` accordingly.
 * Given the asynchronous nature of fetches and initial loads of live `main` and audio/subtitle tracks,
 * the primary purpose of this function is to ensure the "local timelines" of audio/subtitle tracks
 * are aligned to the main/video timeline, using PDT as the cross-reference/"anchor" that should
 * be consistent across playlists, per the HLS spec.
 * @lineNumber
 * 191
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} refDetails

leadingComments.value:
*
 * @desc
 * Computes the PTS of a new level's fragments using the difference in Program Date Time from the last level.
 * @lineNumber
 * 152
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} lastDetails

trailingComments.value: Calculate a delta to apply to all fragments according to the delta in PDT times and start times
of a fragment in the reference details, and a fragment in the target details of the same discontinuity.
If a fragment of the same discontinuity was not found use the middle fragment of both.

leadingComments.value: Calculate a delta to apply to all fragments according to the delta in PDT times and start times
of a fragment in the reference details, and a fragment in the target details of the same discontinuity.
If a fragment of the same discontinuity was not found use the middle fragment of both.

*
 * @desc
 * Ensures appropriate time-alignment between renditions based on PDT. Unlike `alignPDT`, which adjusts
 * the timeline based on the delta between PDTs of the 0th fragment of two playlists/`LevelDetails`,
 * this function assumes the timelines represented in `refDetails` are accurate, including the PDTs,
 * and uses the "wallclock"/PDT timeline as a cross-reference to `details`, adjusting the presentation
 * times/timelines of `details` accordingly.
 * Given the asynchronous nature of fetches and initial loads of live `main` and audio/subtitle tracks,
 * the primary purpose of this function is to ensure the "local timelines" of audio/subtitle tracks
 * are aligned to the main/video timeline, using PDT as the cross-reference/"anchor" that should
 * be consistent across playlists, per the HLS spec.
 * @lineNumber
 * 191
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} refDetails

*
 * @desc
 * Ensures appropriate time-alignment between renditions based on PDT. Unlike `alignPDT`, which adjusts
 * the timeline based on the delta between PDTs of the 0th fragment of two playlists/`LevelDetails`,
 * this function assumes the timelines represented in `refDetails` are accurate, including the PDTs,
 * and uses the "wallclock"/PDT timeline as a cross-reference to `details`, adjusting the presentation
 * times/timelines of `details` accordingly.
 * Given the asynchronous nature of fetches and initial loads of live `main` and audio/subtitle tracks,
 * the primary purpose of this function is to ensure the "local timelines" of audio/subtitle tracks
 * are aligned to the main/video timeline, using PDT as the cross-reference/"anchor" that should
 * be consistent across playlists, per the HLS spec.
 * @lineNumber
 * 191
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} refDetails

*
 * @desc
 * Using the parameters of the last level, this function computes PTS' of the new fragments so that they form a
 * contiguous stream with the last fragments.
 * The PTS of a fragment lets Hls.js know where it fits into a stream - by knowing every PTS, we know which fragment to
 * download at any given time. PTS is normally computed when the fragment is demuxed, so taking this step saves us time

If the PTS wasn't figured out via discontinuity sequence that means there was no CC increase within the level.
Aligning via Program Date Time should therefore be reliable, since PDT should be the same within the same
discontinuity sequence.
Try to align on sn so that we pick a better start fragment.
Do not perform this on playlists with delta updates as this is only to align levels on switch
and adjustSliding only adjusts fragments after skippedSegments.

This check protects the unsafe "!" usage below for null program date time access.
if last level sliding is 1000 and its first frag PROGRAM-DATE-TIME is 2017-08-20 1:10:00 AM
and if new details first frag PROGRAM DATE-TIME is 2017-08-20 1:10:08 AM
then we can deduce that playlist B sliding is 1000+8 = 1008s
hasProgramDateTime check above makes this safe.
date diff is in ms. frag.start is in seconds

*
 * @desc
 * Ensures appropriate time-alignment between renditions based on PDT. Unlike `alignPDT`, which adjusts
 * the timeline based on the delta between PDTs of the 0th fragment of two playlists/`LevelDetails`,
 * this function assumes the timelines represented in `refDetails` are accurate, including the PDTs,
 * and uses the "wallclock"/PDT timeline as a cross-reference to `details`, adjusting the presentation
 * times/timelines of `details` accordingly.
 * Given the asynchronous nature of fetches and initial loads of live `main` and audio/subtitle tracks,
 * the primary purpose of this function is to ensure the "local timelines" of audio/subtitle tracks
 * are aligned to the main/video timeline, using PDT as the cross-reference/"anchor" that should
 * be consistent across playlists, per the HLS spec.
 * @lineNumber
 * 191
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} details
 * @param
 * {LevelDetails} refDetails
Calculate a delta to apply to all fragments according to the delta in PDT times and start times
of a fragment in the reference details, and a fragment in the target details of the same discontinuity.
If a fragment of the same discontinuity was not found use the middle fragment of both.
